DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China’s Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng warned of ‘disastrous consequences’ if the US treats China as an enemy and criticized Washington over reports some Chinese-American scientists were treated unfairly in the US. (SCMP)

 

UK/EU

ComRes poll suggested that UK PM candidate Boris Johnson would win 345 seats in Parliament or a 40-seat majority if a general election was held with him as PM, while Labour would receive 207 seats. (Telegraph)

Whitehall sources suggested that if Boris Johnson becomes the next PM, he cannot wait until the summit in October and must start talks with EU quickly in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit and to secure a new deal he claims to want, while the sources added that preparations for a no-deal will also need to be ramped up. (Guardian)

UK opposition Labour Party is set to declare it will campaign for remain in a second referendum on any deal put to parliament by a Tory PM after union bosses agreed to support a change of policy. (The Guardian)

European Commission designate Von der Leyen reportedly does not see any problems with the UK being granted a Brexit extension after 31st October. (Parliament Magazine)

ECB's Coeure said accommodative policy is needed more than ever and could restart APP if needed. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Vice President Pence said Iran should not confuse US restraint with a lack of US resolve, while he added that US does not want a war and wants talks but will also not back down. Furthermore, VP Pence stated the 2015 Iran nuclear deal is disastrous and that there will be no more pallets of cash for Iran. (Newswires)

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif said that there will not be a better nuclear deal negotiated than the existing one. In related news, the UN atomic watchdog report said Iran has enriched uranium beyond the purity limit agreed in the 2015 nuclear deal and there were also reports that French President Macron's top diplomatic advisors will be travelling to Iran on Tuesday and Wednesday in an attempt to de-escalate US-Iran tensions. (Newswires) 

 

US

US President Trump said the US will no longer deal with the UK ambassador to the US, while he also reiterated criticism of the way UK PM May dealt with Brexit and looks forward to a new PM. (Twitter)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) was under pressure after Rosenblatt downgraded the co. citing concerns over iPhone and iPad sales growth. Boeing (BA) shares fell after the co. lost a Flyadeal order to Airbus. Symantec (SYMC) jumped higher after Broadcom (AVGO) received the necessary financing for its proposed acquisition of the co. Nike (NKE) was buoyant after Chinese rival Anta tumbled after the co. was the focus of a negative short seller report which accused the firm of fraudulent activity. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) moved higher at the open after being mentioned positively at Edgewater in wake of the co.’s recent graphic chip release. Verizon (VZ) were under pressure after the co. was downgraded by Citi. Deutsche Bank ADRs (DB) sunk after the co. announced a massive restructuring, including 18,000 job cuts, an exit to global equities and trading and a reorientation towards European clients. Other notable stocks benefiting from upgrades/mentions included: Gray Television (GTN) was mentioned positively at Barron’s, CrowdStrike (CRWD) benefitted from a number of favourable initiations, JetBlue Airways (JBLU) upgraded at Credit Suisse, Shopify (SHOP) mentioned positively at Barron’s. Stocks suffering as a result of downgrades/negative mentions included: Allegion (ALLE) downgraded at Credit Suisse, American Airlines (AAL) downgraded at Credit Suisse, BNY Mellon (BK) downgraded at Morgan Stanley, Blackstone (BX) downgraded at JMP Securities, Lam Research (LRCX) downgraded at DA Davidson, MSCI (MSCI) downgraded at UBS, State Street (STT) downgraded at Morgan Stanley, Verizon (VZ) downgraded at Citi. S&P 500 -0.5% at 2976, NASDAQ-100 -0.7% at 7786, Dow Jones -0.4% at 26807.

The curve flattened, as traders continue to price out the prospects of a 50bps rate cut at the FOMC's July meeting, after the recent payrolls data placed less urgency on the central bank to fire an insurance rate cut, while the trade truce reached at the G20 last week also mitigates some of the immediate downside risks facing the US/global economy. At settlement the 2s/30s flattened the pronounced by 3.8bps, with the 2-year yield rising just under 1.5bps and the 30-year falling by just under 2.5bps. It is worth noting that markets still expect an insurance cut at the July meeting, where the implied probability of a July cut is around 97% on Monday; desks have been increasingly noting that the Fed has historically rarely disappointed when market expectations have been so aggressive. That is in spite of the economy ticking along nicely. Deutsche Bank's analysts said the strength of the NFP data calls into question whether the Fed should be cutting three times this year at all – the market is currently pricing around 67bps. It is hoped now that Fed Chair Powell will reveal some of the Fed's thinking at his dual testimonies this week (Wed/Thu). US T-note futures (U9) settled 1 tick higher at 127-16.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 8th July 2019: Stocks lower ahead of Wednesday’s Powell Testimony
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries flat, dollar up, crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Iran surpasses uranium enrichment restrictions as expected; Japan imposes tariffs on South Korea semi-conductors whilst EU sets agriculture as a red line in US trade talks;
  • COMING UP: Data; UK BRC Retail Sales, Australia NAB Business Conditions & Confidence, Swiss Unemployment Rate, Italy Retail Sales, US NFIB Business Optimism, Jolts, API Energy Inventories, EIA Short Term Energy Outlook, Speakers; Fed’s Powell, Bullard, Bostic, Quarles, Events; EIA Short Term Energy Outlook & Expanded Forecast Discussion and UK Conservative Party Leaders Debate, Earnings; PepsiCo (PEP).

 

* MARKET WRAP: Risk sentiment begun the week on the back foot, with US stocks moving lower after last week’s strong NFP report reduced expectations for a 50bps rate cut, in addition to a ramping up of trade tensions between Japan and South Korea (the former implementing tariffs on the latter’s exports of semiconductors) which saw the SOX index drag US stocks lower. Analysts also note a lack of upside risk ahead of Powell’s Testimony before Congress on Wednesday, in addition to a lack of share buybacks in the pre-earnings season blackout. Ahead of this week’s supply, the Treasury curve flattened with the front-end yields rising, and the long-end yields falling. The buck built on post NFP gains, whilst crude moved higher, albeit erasing the majority of the day’s gains just before settlement, with participants weighing geopolitical tensions and demand concerns as conflicting driving forces.

* TRADE: Overnight, Japan imposed restrictions on Korean semi-conductor and display material exports, citing national security concerns. Analysts say the latest news highlights that while a US/China trade truce was reached after the G20, global trade developments still have the capacity to introduce further downside risks to the world economy. The SOX index of semiconductors slumped to losses during US hours on the news. Elsewhere, US/China trade tensions continue to bubble: China is expecting to use its plan to name foreign companies that are a national security risk as a bargaining chip in trade talks with US. Additionally, an SCMP columnist has suggested we ignore the hype, and that US President Trump and Chinese President Xi are no closer to an agreement. Moving to the US/EU trade front; EU trade chief Malmstrom reiterated that the EU will not include agriculture in US trade talks. NOTE: agriculture is a key area US President Trump has wanted to show US gains in trade talks, since the industry is one of Trump's key support groups. Malmstrom also said he fears a tariff fight with the US over aircraft aid and repeated EU readiness to negotiate in this area.

* GEOPOLITICAL: Iran has further deviated from the 2015 nuclear deal pact, as expected; an Iran Nuclear Agency spokesperson announced that it has now surpassed the 3.67% uranium enrichment cap, which was later confirmed by a UN atomic watchdog. The spokesperson also said that it was considering enriching uranium at a level greater than 20%, and the next measures in withdrawing from the pact will be greater than the previous. Following the US’ exit from the agreement, the Europeans are the remaining signatories on the pact, and an extended violation from Iran could lead the implementation of tariffs, commentators have noted. In a similar vein, US VP Pence said on Monday that Iran should not confuse US restraint with a lack of US resolve, reiterating Trump’s stance that war is not desired and talks are preferred, but the US will not back down, adding that the US is prepared to protect US interests and personnel in the region. French President Macron's top diplomatic advisors will be travelling to Iran tomorrow and on Wednesday in an attempt to de-escalate US/Iran tensions. Elsewhere, Saudi TV reported that the Saudi-led Coalition Navy had foiled an attempt by Yemen’s Houthi rebels, which reportedly targeted a commercial ship in the Red Sea; however, the Houthis later denied the claims.

* GREECE ELECTIONS: Centre-right New Democracy beat Tsipras' leftist Syriza; new prime minister Mitsotakis will be able to govern with a majority of MPs, and will not have to rely on a coalition partner. UBS has recommended Greek debt to clients on the back of strong (post-restructuring) near-term fiscal profile, relative economic resilience, the prospect of upgrades by rating agencies, and political stability. "Overnight events imply the rally can extend, and a sense of bond market normality could mean Greece trades closer to regional peers such as Portugal," the bank said.

* ECB: ECB's Villeroy suggested that the central bank has "several" meetings to assess the economy, and would act with determination if it needed to act; Villeroy's interview with CNBC comes after a sources report last week hinted that some policymakers saw no urgency to rush into a rate cut at the July meeting.

* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 38bln of new 3-year notes, USD 24bln 10-year re-opening, and USD 16bln 30-year bonds this week. Analysts at UBS says this implied USD 26bln of new cash (ex SOMA-holdings), split between USD 24bln of redemptions, and USD 2bln of coupon payments. Desks have noted that this week's supply will be the first long-end Treasury supply since the June FOMC; the auctions will also be complicated by Fed chair Powell's dual-testimonies to lawmakers (Wed/Thu), with the market looking for signs of whether the Fed is still mulling a July insurance rate cut, now that markets have priced out the prospect of a 'doub'e rate cut, consisting of 50bps. The market is, however, still pricing in a 25bps for the July meeting. The 10-year auction will also be interesting after yields on benchmark 10s recently fell below the 2% handle, though have made its way back above the level in Monday. Analysts at BMO will be watching out for domestic investor fund participation at this cycle's auctions; The bank notes that the funds seem undeterred by the continual bullish repricings in USTs as June's 3-, 10- and 30-year auctions, which showed the largest share on record allocated to that type of investor. Recent averages imply the 3-year auction will tail 0.2bps, covered 2.52x; the breakdown is seen as 38.00% to dealers, 16.3% to directs, and 45.7% to indirects.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 1 TICK HIGHER AT 127-16: The curve flattened, as traders continue to price out the prospects of a 50bps rate cut at the FOMC's July meeting, after the recent payrolls data placed less urgency on the central bank to fire an insurance rate cut, while the trade truce reached at the G20 last week also mitigates some of the immediate downside risks facing the US/global economy. At settlement the 2s/30s flattened the pronounced by 3.8bps, with the 2-year yield rising just under 1.5bps and the 30-year falling by just under 2.5bps. It is worth noting that markets still expect an insurance cut at the July meeting, where the implied probability of a July cut is around 97% on Monday; desks have been increasingly noting that the Fed has historically rarely disappointed when market expectations have been so aggressive. That is in spite of the economy ticking along nicely. Deutsche Bank's analysts said the strength of the NFP data calls into question whether the Fed should be cutting three times this year at all – the market is currently pricing around 67bps. It is hoped now that Fed Chair Powell will reveal some of the Fed's thinking at his dual testimonies this week (Wed/Thu).

* WTI FUTURES (Q9) SETTLE USD 0.15 HIGHER AT USD 57.66/BBL; BRENT FUTURES (U9) SETTLE USD 0.12 LOWER AT USD 64.11/BBL: Energy markets drifted modestly higher to start the week, before reversing course before settlement, following a strong jobs report on Friday providing a mixed signal to a market preparing for rate cuts. Geopolitical tensions in Iran remain price supportive, with Iran making further deviations from the 2015 nuclear pact. At the same time, demand concerns remain a major hurdle for bulls given the global signals of faltering growth across major economies. RBC’s analysts highlighted that in the past five years, the oil market has been supply driven, but going ahead it is more likely be demand driven, making it materially harder to find an equilibrium. RBC also notes that refinery utilisation margins are weak in many regions globally, such as Asia and the Mediterranean, in a time where it should be strong due to peak summer time trends, which the bank believes could be an ominous demand signal, or an excessive supply one, or both. Current US energy inventory expectations for the latest week sees crude drawing by 3.6mln bbls, gasoline stocks are seen drawing 1.2mln bbls and distillates are seen building 1.4mln bbls; Genscape forecasts Cushing as drawing 0.42mln bbls.

* S&P 500 -0.5% at 2976, NASDAQ-100 -0.7% at 7786, Dow Jones -0.4% at 26807, Sectors: Consumer Discretionary 0.2%, Consumer Staples 0.2%, Energy 0.1%, Financials  0.6%, Health Care -0.7%, Industrials -0.7%, Information Technology -0.7%, Materials -1.1%, Services -0.9%, Utilities 0.1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) was under pressure after Rosenblatt downgraded the co. citing concerns over iPhone and iPad sales growth. Boeing (BA) shares fell after the co. lost a Flyadeal order to Airbus. Symantec (SYMC) jumped higher after Broadcom (AVGO) received the necessary financing for its proposed acquisition of the co. Nike (NKE) was buoyant after Chinese rival Anta tumbled after the co. was the focus of a negative short seller report which accused the firm of fraudulent activity. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) moved higher at the open after being mentioned positively at Edgewater in wake of the co.’s recent graphic chip release. Verizon (VZ) were under pressure after the co. was downgraded by Citi. Deutsche Bank ADRs (DB) sunk after the co. announced a massive restructuring, including 18,000 job cuts, an exit to global equities and trading and a reorientation towards European clients. Other notable stocks benefiting from upgrades/mentions included: Gray Television (GTN) was mentioned positively at Barron’s, CrowdStrike (CRWD) benefitted from a number of favourable initiations, JetBlue Airways (JBLU) upgraded at Credit Suisse, Shopify (SHOP) mentioned positively at Barron’s. Stocks suffering as a result of downgrades/negative mentions included: Allegion (ALLE) downgraded at Credit Suisse, American Airlines (AAL) downgraded at Credit Suisse, BNY Mellon (BK) downgraded at Morgan Stanley, Blackstone (BX) downgraded at JMP Securities, Lam Research (LRCX) downgraded at DA Davidson, MSCI (MSCI) downgraded at UBS, State Street (STT) downgraded at Morgan Stanley, Verizon (VZ) downgraded at Citi.

* FX WRAP: USD continued higher as a 50bps rate cut at the July meeting was priced out and traders continue to chew the fat over a decent payroll report on Friday. Dollar strength post-NFP has kept the EUR close to the 1.12 handle. The single currency was unmoved by a market-friendly election outcome in Greece, desks have said that this may be due to less perceived risk around Greece now (when Syriza took power in 2015, the spread between Bunds and Greek 10-year was around 1500bps, but that spread has now narrowed to around 250bps). Attention now turns developments at the ECB (mins to be released on Thursday), and what easing is coming from the central bank in the short-term, before (it is expected) a dovish Christine Lagarde takes the helm. JPY strengthened overnight but within, as has become expected, a thin range, with moves being underpinned by trade war escalations by Japan against South Korea. Albeit, as the US day approached, the buck regained its poise during US hours, USDJPY rising above 108.50. GBP managed to cling onto the 1.25 in the face of the strengthening buck, and despite a brief foray sub the figure. Technicians say 1.2481 is the next key support to the downside (the post-NFP low). AUD: Data showed job adverts rebounding in June (+4.6% M/M vs -8.2% M/M in May), but Aussie has relinquished 0.70 in the face of the buck strength, and in spite of yuan stability, helping it to largely shrug-off ramping up of tensions between key Asian economies Japan and South Korea. EMFX look set to take cues from what sort of a message Powell sends about insurance rate cuts (erring dovishly should generally keep EMFX supported, analysts say, while any push-back may heap pressure on the complex). The MXN and BRL traded firmer despite USD strength, with hawkish Banxico said to be supporting the peso, while BRL investors positioned for a positive outcome in the upcoming pension vote. TRY sunk after CBRT independence took a major hit: President Erdogan had Governor Centinkaya fired, replacing him with his deputy (and new) Governor Uysal, Turkish media reported. No official reason has been provided, but press reports suggest it was as a result of Centinkaya's refusal to cut interest rates was the driving factor, something President Erdogan has repeatedly called for previously. SocGen's analysts now see sharp rate cuts coming, perhaps as soon as the 25th July meeting.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: some blows to Central Bank Independence just days after July 4th
content:
DXY

The broad Dollar and index are edging higher again, but the DXY remains just shy of its post-NFP high (97.466) within a 97.398-161 range awaiting this week’s key events that kick off on Wednesday with Fed chair Powell’s semi-annual testimony part 1. On that note, Friday’s US jobs data has raised the bar for the July FOMC in terms aggressive easing as a ½ point ease has now been virtually priced out, but President Trump has not relented from his criticism of the Fed for keeping monetary policy too tight. In fact, he was arguably even more adamant that Powell and co pose the biggest problem for the domestic economy not the country’s competitors and the policy-makers are clueless, as rates would be lower if they knew what to do.

TRY

The Lira is off worst levels, but still reeling after the even more radical action taken by Turkish President Erdogan to influence the CBRT and lower official rates. To recap, Deputy Central Bank head Uysal was handed the reins after the sacking of Cetinkaya due to the latter not cutting benchmarks last month and/or signalling enough of a move at the July 25 policy meeting. However, the onus is now on Uysal to deliver as markets are pricing in at least 100 bp worth of easing. Usd/Try is hovering around 5.7270 within a 5.7930-5.6300 range and the AK Party also announced plans to align CBRT reserves with trade laws.

CHF/JPY 

Lagging their G10 peers and extending losses vs the Greenback as the Franc edged down towards 0.9950 and just shy of 1.1150 against the Euro, while the Yen hit 108.72 in wake of weaker than expected Japanese machinery orders data and Usd/Jpy climbed further away from decent option expiry interest in the low 108.00 zone.

EUR/GBP

The single currency and Sterling are both struggling to stay above big figures vs the Greenback, at 1.1200 and 1.2500 respectively, with the former plagued by more worrying Eurozone data/survey news and the latter still suffering from UK political and Brexit uncertainty. In terms technicals, Eur/Usd has near term support from 1.1180-70 and Cable traded down to circa 1.2480 in wake of last Friday’s US jobs data, but comments from BoE’s Haldane may offer fresh direction.

NZD/CAD/AUD

All narrowly mixed vs their US counterpart, as the Kiwi erased all its recovery gains to retest 0.6624 lows and the Loonie slipped back towards 1.3100 despite firmer oil prices and the looming BoC meeting on Wednesday. Meanwhile, the Aussie retreated a tad further from highs not far from 0.7000 to around 0.6970 in wake of overnight press reports playing down the G20 US-China trade truce on the basis that there is still a way to go before any deal is done, adding that China could use a list of foreign companies that pose a security threat as a bargaining chip.

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

Morgan Stanley has downgraded global equities to underweight, commenting that risk reward appears poor. The bank says earnings estimates are too high and, as such, Q2 earnings could result in an adjustment. MS added that it had reduced overall equity weighting by reducing holdings in US and EM equities and said that it prefers equities in Japan and Europe.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – Rosenblatt cut its rating on the co. to sell from neutral. The analysts believe new iPhone sales will be disappointing, iPad sales growth will slow in H2 2019 and, more generally, the co. will face “fundamental deterioration” over the next 6-12 months.
  • Procter & Gamble’s (PG) (Consumer Staples/Personal Products) Ventures unit is looking to enter the pest control industry with its Zevo spray, pitting it against incumbent Raid, reported the WSJ. Reportedly, unlike Raid sprays, Zevo uses a chemical that is benign to humans/animals.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) - Flyadeal, a Saudi Arabian airline, have cancelled an order for 30 Boeing 737 Max planes, opting to go with Airbus (AIR FP) instead.
  • Verizon Communications (VZ) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) has been downgraded to neutral at Citi. Analyst Michael Rollins believes that long-term risks are rising for both industry pricing and margins, given the “widening array of possible outcomes" for the proposed merger of T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S).

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class C (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is in talks with Dish Network (DISH) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite) to create a fourth US wireless carrier reported The New York Post. However, 9to5Google later reported that Google said the NY Post claims were “simply false”.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail), Shopify (SHOP) – Barron’s comments that Shopify, whose revenue has grown 80% per year over the past five years, has taken another step closer to becoming a viable alternative to Amazon; the co. unveiled its Fulfillment Network which will allow merchants to offer deliveries under their own branding, along with better shipping rates. Elsewhere, Cowen believes Amazon's Prime 1-day delivery is likely to drive higher conversion rates. The co. maintained its USD 2500 price target for Amazon.
  • Broadcom Inc. (AVGO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has secured financing for its proposed acquisition of Symantec (SYMC) (Information Technology/Application Software) in an all-cash deal which would value the cybersecurity co. at over USD 22bln (including debt).
  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) has apologised after six police officers were asked to leave one of its stores in Tempe, Arizona, which caused a social media backlash.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), Twitter, Inc. (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - The White House has opted not to invite Facebook or Twitter (who have both been frequently accused of political bias by US President Trump) to its upcoming social media summit.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) CEO Musk has hinted that once the technological problems currently holding up the widespread adoption of self-driving cars, the company may stop selling cars directly to consumers, rather the co. would add vehicles to its still hypothetical fleet of robotaxis. 

S&P 500

  • General Motors’s (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) Cruise, a self-driving vehicle company, have had a USD 2.25 billion investment from Softbank approved by a US national security panel, giving Softbank a seat on the board.

OTHER

  • Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. is to cut 18k jobs by 2022 to 74k jobs, as part of a cost reduction programme which is to reduce adj. costs to EUR 17bln in 2020 and a cost income ratio target of 70%; as such, Co. anticipate restructuring charges of EUR 3bln in Q2 2019, with additional charges expected to total EUR 7.4bln by 2022. Co. confirm that no dividend is to be paid for the next two years. Co. are to create a net capital release unit to manage the unravelling of assets, which represent EUR 74bln of risk-weighted assets and EUR 288bln of leverage exposure. Co’s investment bank’s balance sheet allocation to trading is to be cut by 40%. Co. anticipate reporting a net Q2 loss before income tax of EUR 500mln and a net loss of EUR 2.8bln; excluding this, Co. anticipate reporting Q2 income before tax of EUR 400mn and net profit of EUR 120mln. Co. are now intending on operating with a minimum CET1 ratio of 12.5%, after consultation with regulators and have reached an agreement with BNP Paribas (BNP FP) to ensure service continuity for prime finance and electronic equity clients.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

8th July 2019

· European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] are little changed thus far, with Deutsche Bank’s restructuring capturing the equity markets focus

·  China is expected to use its plan to name foreign companies that are a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade talks with US, SCMP notes that US & China are no closer to a deal

·  Iran has reportedly surpassed the 3.67% uranium enrichment cap, discussions on exceeding 20% have been taken but no decision yet

·  Looking ahead, highlights include BoE’s Haldane

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week with firm losses as the region reacted to the weakness last Friday on Wall St. ASX 200 (-1.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) were lower in which the commodity-related sectors led the broad declines in Australia, especially gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the USD 1400/oz level as a function of a stronger USD and tempered rate cut calls, while Tokyo sentiment was also downbeat as participants digested data releases including a contraction in Machinery Orders. Hang Seng (-1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.6%) were the laggards after continued PBoC liquidity inaction and further clashes between police and protesters who have now targeted tourist areas in Kowloon. In addition, there were suggestions the US-China trade truce at the G20 has done little to bring the sides closer to an actual trade agreement and it is also expected that China could use its plan to name foreign companies a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade discussions. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they tracked the decline in T-notes and rebound in yields in the aftermath of the strong US jobs data, with the absence of the BoJ in the market also contributing to the lack of demand for bonds.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8881 (Prev. 6.8697)

China is expected to use its plan to name foreign companies that are a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade talks with US. In related news, a SCMP columnist suggested to ignore the hype and that US President Trump and Chinese President Xi are no closer to an agreement. (SCMP) 

China FX Reserves (USD)(Jun) 3.119T vs. Exp. 3.110T (Prev. 3.101T). (Newswires)

Japanese Machinery Orders (May) M/M -7.8% vs. Exp. -4.7% (Prev. 5.2%) Japanese Machinery Orders (May) Y/Y -3.7% vs. Exp. -3.9% (Prev. 2.5%)

US

US President Trump said the Fed does not have a clue and that the most difficult problem for the US is the Fed and not the nation’s competitors, while he separately commented that the Fed would lower rates if it knew what it was doing. Furthermore, Trump said that China is devaluing its currency and that the UK Ambassador to the US has not served the UK well. (Newswires)

UK/EU

A YouGov poll over the weekend showed UK PM candidate Boris Johnson with 74% of support vs. 26% for Jeremy Hunt, while it was also reported that Home Secretary Javid backs Johnson as he sees him as better placed to deliver what we need to do at this critical time. (Newswires)

British lawmakers from both the ruling Conservatives and opposition Labour said they were examining steps to prevent the next PM from pursuing a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires) More specifically, Dominic Grieve is planning on amending a bill in Parliament on Monday, to ensure the House of Commons is sitting in October in order to prevent the next PM from suspending legislature to pursue a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

Britain could reportedly be facing a EUR 200bln EU bail-out bill unless it manages a clean Brexit, according to a group which represents numerous pro-Brexit campaigning organisations. (Telegraph)

ECB's Villeroy said if and when needed, there must be no doubt about our determination and capacity to act. Villeroy also suggested that the ECB looks at markets but are data dependent, while he added that the ECB cannot make miracles and it is up to political leaders to reduce uncertainty. (Newswires)

Germany’s CDU Chairwoman Kramp-Karrenbauer warned junior coalition partners against blocking the appointment of a German as the next European Commission President as it would put their coalition under “maximum strain”. (Newswires)

Greece’s centre-right New Democracy party won a landslide victory over incumbent Syriza party, which led to outgoing PM Tsipras conceding defeat to New Democracy leader Kyriakos Mitsotakis. (Guardian)

German Trade Balance, EUR, SA* May 18.7B vs. Exp. 17.0B (Prev. 17.0B, Rev. 16.9B)

- German Industrial Output MM* May 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -1.9%, Rev. -2.0%)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said Iran better be careful and that it is doing a lot of bad things, while he added that Iran will never have a nuclear weapon. (Newswires)

Iran Defence Minister said the downing of the US drone sends a message that Iran will defend its borders. (Newswires)

Iran has surpassed the 3.67% uranium enrichment cap, according to a Iran Nuclear Energy Spokesman; additionally, enriching uranium above 20% has been discussed at the Supreme National Security Council but no decision has been taken as of yet; Iran’s 3rd step in reducing commitments under the 2015 nuclear deal will be stronger. Follows earlier reports that Iran is to lift uranium enrichment to over 3.67%, while an Iranian official confirmed they will scale back commitment to the 2015 nuclear deal and will keep reducing its commitments every 60 days unless signatories move to protect it from US sanctions and signal room for diplomacy. (Newswires/FARS)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are little changed this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%] though bourses have been somewhat choppy. Deutsche Bank (-0.1%) have announced a major restructuring programme (full details available in the EU Equity Opening News) which includes 18k job cuts by 2022 and the creation of a net capital release unit representing EUR 74bln of risk-weighted assets. In addition, no dividend is to be paid for the next two years and they anticipate a Q2 net loss of EUR 2.8bln. The bank opened firmer this morning by around 3.5%, as markets initially had positive expectations for the Co’s plan; notably the FT highlight that UBS’s share prices roughly doubled in the 3 years after they announced a very similar plan in 2012. However, Co. shares have since given up these gains as further comments have been released by the Co for instance that they see significant uncertainty in their forecast to at least break even in 2020. Unsurprisingly, the banking sector has moved largely in sympathy the German bank this morning, currently lower by around 0.2%. Elsewhere, Pirelli (+4.0%) reside at the top of the FTSE MIB after being upgraded to overweight from neutral at JP Morgan. Finally, Sodexo (-4.1%) are in the red this morning post-earnings, where the Co. indicated that FY19 operating profit is to towards the lower end of the previously announced range.

Apple (AAPL) – Rosenblatt believe that new iPhone sales will be disappointing and iPad sales growth will slow in H2 2019, believe that the Co. will face a fundamental deterioration over the next 6-12 months. (Newswires)

FX

 

NZD/TRY - Vastly contrasting starts to the new week for the Kiwi and Lira, as Nzd/Usd rebounds firmly from post-NFP lows to probe above 0.6650, but Usd/Try extends gains to just over 5.7930 at one stage on the back of further Government intervention aimed at forcing the Turkish CB to cut rates. In short, President Erdogan sacked CBRT chief Cetinkaya over the weekend by decree and put Deputy Governor Uysal in charge and it seems that the failure to cut rates at the June policy meeting and/or not signalling sufficiently aggressive easing for this month prompted the decree and change of leadership.

USD - The Dollar has eased back from Friday’s headline payrolls peaks across the board, not just against the Kiwi as noted above, with the DXY unable to sustain momentum or breach 97.500 to expose the next upside technical objective. Another verbal lashing from US President Trump about the Fed not helping the economy, along the lines of his Turkish counterpart may be weighing on the index and Greenback generally, as markets brace for Powell’s semi-annual testimony to gauge whether easing is on the cards for the July FOMC, and more importantly if there is more than merely an insurance cut in the offing. On that note, markets are 97.5% certain that Funds will be lowered by 25 bp vs just 2.5% still looking for -50 bp.

AUD - The next best major, but capped ahead of 0.7000 as the Aud/Nzd cross drifts back down to 1.0500 from rebound highs posted in wake of last week’s RBA rate cut and tweak in guidance to signal a pause after 2 in a row.

GBP/JPY/CAD/EUR/CHF - All narrowly mixed against the Usd as Cable consolidates in a narrow range north of 1.2500 and the Yen pares some losses between 108.58-29 amidst weaker than forecast Japanese data (machinery orders) and with decent option expiry interest sitting just below (1.2 bn from 108.25-15 and 1 bn from 108.05-00). Meanwhile, the Loonie has also found its footing after underperforming on Friday when Canadian jobs data revealed an unexpected decline, but the breakdown was not as bleak, with Usd/Cad meandering in a 1.3062-83 range, and the single currency has shrugged off a surprise deterioration in Sentix sentiment to hold above 1.1200 in a 1.1219-34 band. Note, expiries could keep Eur/Usd in check given 2.5 bn sitting at 1.1250-55 and 1.1260-65, while the Franc is midway between 0.9900-19 and straddling 1.1125 vs the Euro in lacklustre mood overall.

Turkey Central Bank Governor Cetinkaya was removed from position and replaced by Deputy Governor Uysal in which President Erdogan cited a refusal to cut rates as the reason behind the dismissal. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries:

- EUR/USD: 1.1250-55 (1BLN), 1.1260-65 (1.5BLN), 1.1310-20 (2BLN)

- AUD/JPY: 75.58 (870M), 76.80 (690M)

- USD/JPY: 108.00-05 (1BLN), 108.15-25 (1.2BLN), 108.50 (450M)

 

FIXED INCOME 

Bunds are just off a marginal new Eurex low of 173.36 as the post-NFP rebound fades further, but Gilts and US Treasuries continue to trade nearer the tops of their recovery ranges or at fresh highs (like 131.90 for the former on Liffe), while Spanish debt has reversed all and more of its earlier gains with 10 year benchmark down to 157.75 vs 158.76 at one stage and last Friday’s 158.16 close. Bonos appear to have resumed their post-supply retracement from fresh peaks and yield lows and dragging the rest of the Eurozone bond complex down, or at least capping the upside. Ahead, relatively quiet pm agenda, with US employment trends and consumer trends flanking BoE’s Haldane.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent have had a jittery start to the week and are trading within a relatively narrow USD 0.50/bbl range, with the complex continuing to garner some support from Friday’s price action where WTI reclaimed the USD 57.00/bbl level on Friday and is approaching the USD 58.00/bbl level; session high of USD 57.91. Recent commentary for the complex has been relatively light, Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh said he is hopeful that Iran’s oil exports will improve and the main concern is Iran’s ability to export oil not the price of oil. Elsewhere, Ineos’ Forties Pipeline System’s (575k BPD) oil flows are to be continually reduced as a processing unit is in need of maintenance; flows are expected to be reduced to 150mln BPD until Tuesday. Separately, Goldman Sachs have reiterated their stance that they continue to see WTI between USD 50-60/bbl and Brent between USD 55-65/bbl. Looking ahead, this week we have the three main monthly oil market reports beginning with the EIA’s STE tomorrow at 17:00 BST which includes their expanded forecast discussion.

Gold (+0.5%) is firmer this morning as the metal has once again surpassed the USD 1400/oz level to the upside after losing the handle last week post US jobs report. Of note for the yellow metal, PBoC added 0.33mln ounces of gold to their reserve stockpile in June, to a total of 61.94mln ounces; the PBoC’s seventh consecutive months of gold buying. Separately, copper has been largely resilient to the downside seen in Asia overnight, with the red metal firmer by jut shy of 1.0% this morning; though does trade within a narrow range on the day thus far.

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh said he is hopeful that Iran’s crude oil exports will improve, while he added that the price of oil is not Iran's main concern and that what matters is the amount Iran can export. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs continue to see WTI between USD 50-60/bbl and Brent between USD 55-65/bbl. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Deutsche Bank’s downsizing dominates a low key start to pivotal week  - 8th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

EQUITIES

Major European indices are little changed this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] though bourses have been somewhat choppy. Deutsche Bank (-0.1%) have announced a major restructuring programme (full details available in the EU Equity Opening News) which includes 18k job cuts by 2022 and the creation of a net capital release unit representing EUR 74bln of risk-weighted assets. In addition, no dividend is to be paid for the next two years and they anticipate a Q2 net loss of EUR 2.8bln. The bank opened firmer this morning by around 3.5%, as markets initially had positive expectations for the Co’s plan; notably the FT highlight that UBS’s share prices roughly doubled in the 3 years after they announced a very similar plan in 2012. However, Co. shares have since given up these gains as further comments have been released by the Co for instance that they see significant uncertainty in their forecast to at least break even in 2020. Unsurprisingly, the banking sector has moved largely in sympathy the German bank this morning, currently lower by around 0.2%. Elsewhere, Pirelli (+4.0%) reside at the top of the FTSE MIB after being upgraded to overweight from neutral at JP Morgan. Finally, Sodexo (-4.1%) are in the red this morning post-earnings, where the Co. indicated that FY19 operating profit is to towards the lower end of the previously announced range.

FX

NZD/TRY - Vastly contrasting starts to the new week for the Kiwi and Lira, as Nzd/Usd rebounds firmly from post-NFP lows to probe above 0.6650, but Usd/Try extends gains to just over 5.7930 at one stage on the back of further Government intervention aimed at forcing the Turkish CB to cut rates. In short, President Erdogan sacked CBRT chief Cetinkaya over the weekend by decree and put Deputy Governor Uysal in charge and it seems that the failure to cut rates at the June policy meeting and/or not signalling sufficiently aggressive easing for this month prompted the decree and change of leadership.

USD - The Dollar has eased back from Friday’s headline payrolls peaks across the board, not just against the Kiwi as noted above, with the DXY unable to sustain momentum or breach 97.500 to expose the next upside technical objective. Another verbal lashing from US President Trump about the Fed not helping the economy, along the lines of his Turkish counterpart may be weighing on the index and Greenback generally, as markets brace for Powell’s semi-annual testimony to gauge whether easing is on the cards for the July FOMC, and more importantly if there is more than merely an insurance cut in the offing. On that note, markets are 97.5% certain that Funds will be lowered by 25 bp vs just 2.5% still looking for -50 bp.

AUD - The next best major, but capped ahead of 0.7000 as the Aud/Nzd cross drifts back down to 1.0500 from rebound highs posted in wake of last week’s RBA rate cut and tweak in guidance to signal a pause after 2 in a row.

GBP/JPY/CAD/EUR/CHF - All narrowly mixed against the Usd as Cable consolidates in a narrow range north of 1.2500 and the Yen pares some losses between 108.58-29 amidst weaker than forecast Japanese data (machinery orders) and with decent option expiry interest sitting just below (1.2 bn from 108.25-15 and 1 bn from 108.05-00). Meanwhile, the Loonie has also found its footing after underperforming on Friday when Canadian jobs data revealed an unexpected decline, but the breakdown was not as bleak, with Usd/Cad meandering in a 1.3062-83 range, and the single currency has shrugged off a surprise deterioration in Sentix sentiment to hold above 1.1200 in a 1.1219-34 band. Note, expiries could keep Eur/Usd in check given 2.5 bn sitting at 1.1250-55 and 1.1260-65, while the Franc is midway between 0.9900-19 and straddling 1.1125 vs the Euro in lacklustre mood overall.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds are just off a marginal new Eurex low of 173.36 as the post-NFP rebound fades further, but Gilts and US Treasuries continue to trade nearer the tops of their recovery ranges or at fresh highs (like 131.90 for the former on Liffe), while Spanish debt has reversed all and more of its earlier gains with 10 year benchmark down to 157.75 vs 158.76 at one stage and last Friday’s 158.16 close. Separately, Goldman Sachs have reiterated their stance that they continue to see WTI between USD 50-60/bbl and Brent between USD 55-65/bbl. Looking ahead, this week we have the three main monthly oil market reports beginning with the EIA’s STE tomorrow at 17:00 BST which includes their expanded forecast discussion.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

8th July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with firm losses as the region reacted to the weakness last Friday on Wall St. ASX 200 (-1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower in which the commodity-related sectors led the broad declines in Australia, especially gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the USD 1400/oz level as a function of a stronger USD and tempered rate cut calls, while Tokyo sentiment was also downbeat as participants digested data releases including a contraction in Machinery Orders. Hang Seng (-1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) were the laggards after continued PBoC liquidity inaction and further clashes between police and protesters who have now targeted tourist areas in Kowloon. In addition, there were suggestions the US-China trade truce at the G20 has done little to bring the sides closer to an actual trade agreement and it is also expected that China could use its plan to name foreign companies a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade discussions

FTSE 100

SSE (SSE LN) – Co. and British Gas are to remove petrol and diesel from their fleets by 2030. (Newswires)

BT Group (BT/ LN) – Co. has reportedly hired Credit Suisse to seek a potential purchaser for its Spanish business. (Newswires)

GVC (GVC LN) – Co. are subject to additional questions on their corporate governance following suggestions that the Co. offloaded their unregulated Turkish unit in 2017, to a business partner of the Co’s CEO. A Co. spokesman has subsequently stated that such suggestions are ‘unfounded’ and everything was done to ‘regulatory requirements’. (Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. is to cut 18k jobs by 2022 to 74k jobs, as part of a cost reduction programme which is to reduce adj. costs to EUR 17bln in 2020 and a cost income ratio target of 70%; as such, Co. anticipate restructuring charges of EUR 3bln in Q2 2019, with additional charges expected to total EUR 7.4bln by 2022. Co. confirm that no dividend is to be paid for the next two years. Co. are to create a net capital release unit to manage the unravelling of assets, which represent EUR 74bln of risk-weighted assets and EUR 288bln of leverage exposure. Co’s investment bank’s balance sheet allocation to trading is to be cut by 40%. Co. anticipate reporting a net Q2 loss before income tax of EUR 500mln and a net loss of EUR 2.8bln; excluding this, Co. anticipate reporting Q2 income before tax of EUR 400mn and net profit of EUR 120mln. subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 8th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets began the week with firm losses as the region reacted to the weakness last Friday on Wall St
  • China is expected to use its plan to name foreign companies that are a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade talks with US
  • A YouGov poll over the weekend showed UK PM candidate Boris Johnson with 74% of support vs. 26% for Jeremy Hunt
  • TRY weakened more than 2% against USD after the Turkish Central Bank Governor was ousted and replaced by his deputy
  • Iran is reportedly to lift uranium enrichment to over 3.67%, while an Iranian official confirmed they will scale back commitment to the 2015 nuclear deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German trade and BoE’s Haldane

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week with firm losses as the region reacted to the weakness last Friday on Wall St. ASX 200 (-1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower in which the commodity-related sectors led the broad declines in Australia, especially gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the USD 1400/oz level as a function of a stronger USD and tempered rate cut calls, while Tokyo sentiment was also downbeat as participants digested data releases including a contraction in Machinery Orders. Hang Seng (-1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) were the laggards after continued PBoC liquidity inaction and further clashes between police and protesters who have now targeted tourist areas in Kowloon. In addition, there were suggestions the US-China trade truce at the G20 has done little to bring the sides closer to an actual trade agreement and it is also expected that China could use its plan to name foreign companies a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade discussions. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they tracked the decline in T-notes and rebound in yields in the aftermath of the strong US jobs data, with the absence of the BoJ in the market also contributing to the lack of demand for bonds.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8881 (Prev. 6.8697)

China is expected to use its plan to name foreign companies that are a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade talks with US. In related news, a SCMP columnist suggested to ignore the hype and that US President Trump and Chinese President Xi are no closer to an agreement. (SCMP) 

China FX Reserves (USD)(Jun) 3.119T vs. Exp. 3.110T (Prev. 3.101T). (Newswires)

Japanese Machinery Orders (May) M/M -7.8% vs. Exp. -4.7% (Prev. 5.2%) Japanese Machinery Orders (May) Y/Y -3.7% vs. Exp. -3.9% (Prev. 2.5%)

UK/EU

A YouGov poll over the weekend showed UK PM candidate Boris Johnson with 74% of support vs. 26% for Jeremy Hunt, while it was also reported that Home Secretary Javid backs Johnson as he sees him as better placed to deliver what we need to do at this critical time. (Newswires)

British lawmakers from both the ruling Conservatives and opposition Labour said they were examining steps to prevent the next PM from pursuing a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires) More specifically, Dominic Grieve is planning on amending a bill in Parliament on Monday, to ensure the House of Commons is sitting in October in order to prevent the next PM from suspending legislature to pursue a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires) 

Britain could reportedly be facing a EUR 200bln EU bail-out bill unless it manages a clean Brexit, according to a group which represents numerous pro-Brexit campaigning organisations. (Telegraph)

ECB's Villeroy said if and when needed, there must be no doubt about our determination and capacity to act. Villeroy also suggested that the ECB looks at markets but are data dependent, while he added that the ECB cannot make miracles and it is up to political leaders to reduce uncertainty. (Newswires)

Germany’s CDU Chairwoman Kramp-Karrenbauer warned junior coalition partners against blocking the appointment of a German as the next European Commission President as it would put their coalition under “maximum strain”. (Newswires)

Greece’s centre-right New Democracy party won a landslide victory over incumbent Syriza party, which led to outgoing PM Tsipras conceding defeat to New Democracy leader Kyriakos Mitsotakis. (Guardian)

FX

 

The greenback was relatively stable although has slightly pulled back from post-NFP highs in which the better than expected jobs data pushed the DXY back above 97.00. As such, markets have only priced in a less than 5% chance of a 50bps rate cut at this month’s FOMC vs. more than 32% over a week ago and the probability of a 25bps cut is now at over 95%. EUR/USD and GBP/USD traded rangebound and failed to make any significant recovery from Friday’s pressure in which the latter briefly gave up the 1.2500 handle to the downside, while the latest YouGov polls over the weekend also showed that UK PM candidate and hardcore Brexiteer Boris Johnson was firmly in the lead with 74% of support vs. 26% for Jeremy Hunt. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were little changed with only minimal flows seen into the safe-haven JPY despite the deterioration in risk sentiment and antipodeans also followed suit to the humdrum tone, while the biggest mover was TRY which weakened more than 2% against USD after the Turkish Central Bank Governor was ousted and replaced by his deputy which President Erdogan stated was due to the former Governor’s unwillingness to lower rates.

 

Turkey Central Bank Governor Cetinkaya was removed from position and replaced by Deputy Governor Uysal in which President Erdogan cited a refusal to cut rates as the reason behind the dismissal. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful overnight with WTI crude futures holding onto last Friday’s US gains where prices reclaimed the USD 57.00/bbl level which then later acted as support. In terms of fundamentals, it was reported that Saudi Arabia output was at 9.8mln BPD in June vs. 9.7mln BPD in May which although is a slight increased, remains comfortably below the OPEC+ commitment of 10.3mln BPD, and geopolitical concerns continue to linger as Iran confirmed it will scale back commitment to the 2015 nuclear deal. Elsewhere, gold was lacklustre following its recent slip below USD 1400/oz in the aftermath of the NFP data although prices within close proximity for an attempt to reclaim the level, while copper conformed to the rangebound trade across the complex and has so far shrugged off the negative risk tone in the region as well as the hefty losses in its largest buyer China. Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh said he is hopeful that Iran’s crude oil exports will improve, while he added that the price of oil is not Iran's main concern and that what matters is the amount Iran can export. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump said Iran better be careful and that it is doing a lot of bad things, while he added that Iran will never have a nuclear weapon. (Newswires)

Iran was reportedly to lift uranium enrichment to over 3.67%, while an Iranian official confirmed they will scale back commitment to the 2015 nuclear deal and will keep reducing its commitments every 60 days unless signatories move to protect it from US sanctions and signal room for diplomacy. (Newswires/FARS)

Iran Defence Minister said the downing of the US drone sends a message that Iran will defend its borders. (Newswires)

 

US

 

US yields rose sharply after the June employment situation report surprised to the upside, and the internals of the report also provided encouragement that the labour market is in decent shape. Bear-flattening was the play after the data, and there was a significant paring back in the implied probabilities of a 50bps rate cut at the Fed’s July meeting – the probability has now fallen to just 0.5% from around 27% before the data, though the market is still completely priced for a 25bps cut; money markets now price 60bps of easing through the end of the year, compared to 75bps at the close of business on Thursday. Interestingly, Treasuries only marginally recovered from lows, despite equities paring back the NFP-induced slide. US T-note futures (U9) settled 25 ticks lower at 127-15.

US President Trump said the Fed does not have a clue and that the most difficult problem for the US is the Fed and not the nation’s competitors, while he separately commented that the Fed would lower rates if it knew what it was doing. Furthermore, Trump said that China is devaluing its currency and that the UK Ambassador to the US has not served the UK well. (Newswires)

Fed Board nominee Shelton said the jobs report shows Trump’s agenda is working, while she added that she does not want the Fed to 'pull the rug' from under the market and that markets are not wrong in questioning the yield curve. Furthermore, Shelton echoed Trump comments on ECB looking to devalue the EUR and suggested that competitive devaluation is cheating not competing. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded negative after NFP data dampened Fed rate cut prospects and as Chinese stocks slumped
content: Asia equity markets began the week with firm losses as the region reacted to the weakness last Friday on Wall St where better than expected NFP jobs data dampened Fed rate cut hopes. ASX 200 (-1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower in which the commodity-related sectors led the broad declines in Australia, especially gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the USD 1400/oz level as a function of a stronger USD and tempered rate cut calls, while Tokyo sentiment was also downbeat as participants digested data releases including a contraction in Machinery Orders. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) were the laggards after continued PBoC liquidity inaction and further clashes between police and protesters who have now targeted tourist areas in Kowloon. In addition, there were suggestions the US-China trade truce at the G20 has done little to bring the sides closer to an actual trade agreement and it is also expected that China could use its plan to name foreign companies a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade discussions. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they tracked the decline in T-notes and rebound in yields in the aftermath of the strong US jobs data, with the absence of the BoJ in the market also contributing to the lack of demand for bonds.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades negative after NFP data dampens Fed rate cut prospects and as Chinese stocks spiral down
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week negative as the region reacts to the weakness last Friday on Wall St where the major indices finished lower after better than expected NFP jobs data dampened Fed rate cut hopes. ASX 200 (-1.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) are lower with the commodity-related sectors leading the broad declines in Australia especially gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the USD 1400/oz level as a function of a stronger USD and tempered rate cut calls, while Tokyo sentiment is also downbeat as participants digest latest data releases including a contraction in Machinery Orders. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.6%) are the laggards after continued PBoC liquidity inaction and further clashes between police and protesters who have now targeted tourist areas in Kowloon. In addition, there were suggestions the US-China trade truce at the G20 has done little to bring the sides closer to an actual trade agreement and it is also expected that China could use its plan to name foreign companies a national security risk, as a bargaining chip in trade discussions.

In FX markets, the greenback is relatively stable although has slightly pulled back from post-NFP highs in which the better than expected jobs data dampened hopes of a rate cut by the Fed later this month and pushed the DXY back above the 97.00 level. As such, markets have only priced in a less than 5% chance of a 50bps rate cut at this month’s FOMC vs. more than 32% over a week ago and the probability of a 25bps cut is now at over 95%. EUR/USD and GBP/USD trade rangebound and have failed to make any significant recovery from Friday’s weakness in which the latter briefly gave up the 1.2500 handle to the downside, while the latest YouGov polls over the weekend also showed that UK PM candidate and hardcore Brexiteer Boris Johnson is firmly in the lead with 74% of support vs. 26% for Jeremy Hunt. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are little changed with only minimal flows seen into the safe-haven JPY despite the deterioration in risk sentiment and antipodeans are also uneventful, while the biggest mover has been TRY which weakened more than 2% against USD after the Turkish Central Bank Governor was ousted and replaced by his deputy which President Erdogan stated was due to the former Governor’s unwillingness to lower rates.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as they track the weakness in T-notes and rebound in yields in the aftermath of the strong US jobs data, with the absence of the BoJ in the market also contributing to the lack of demand for bonds.
